Title: (Nearly) Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Active Recognizers (but were Afraid to Ask )
Abstract: This presentation will provide a concise, but thorough, review of one of the more unique features of the F# language: active recognizers. Also known as active patterns, this feature allows one to extend the pattern-matching capabilities of the language. Active recognizers may be put to great effect in taming unruly APIs, improving the declarative style of one's code, constructing embedded DSLs, and much more. This talk will be given in a lecture format, interspersing digestible code samples with detailed breakdown of syntax. Additional consideration will be given, time permitting, to appropriate use-cases for active recognizers and a discussion of the under-lying mechanics. The review is aimed at advanced beginners who are familiar with F#'s general syntax and usage. Also, while not strictly necessary, those wishing to follow along via computer are encouraged to have, at least, version 2.0 of the core F# tools. Information on obtaining the latest version of F# (for your platform of choice) may be found at: http://fsharp.org.

Title: “So UX Designers Just Make Things Pretty, Right?” & Other Myths Debunked
Abstract:
Using real-world examples from applications such as retailer data visualizations, healthcare websites, and control engineering mobile and desktop software, Kaitlan illustrates how UX      

* challenges design thinking and builds consensus in companies both large and small,   
* drives Interaction Design, Information Architecture, and Content Strategy, and   
* dispels pervasive over-simplifications, such as “UX = Graphic Design” and “Fewer clicks = good UX”.      

If you’ve ever questioned the need for UX in your project, this talk is for you.     

Topics:   
* UX ≠ Visual Design   
* UX application in Agile environment   
* Fewer clicks ≠ Good UX   
* UX-driven Information Architecture   
* UX-driven Interaction Design   
* UX-driven Content Strategy

Title: 5 Things I Wish Someone Had Told Me About Programming Before I Started
Abstract: There's more to being a successful developer than simply being great at programming. The gotchas that slow us down or trip us up are often outside of the code we write, manifesting instead in our process or how we work with our peers. Whether you're new to programming or a veteran of many projects, these 5 things can improve your code, your career, and your team. If you're just starting out, you'll be glad to hear that you frustrations are not unique -- there are strategies for overcoming them. For experienced developers, this talk is a refresher course on what goes into the day-to-day, remind

Title: 8 Simple TDD Rules
Abstract:
After using TDD for over 10 years to build software, I've seen and used every anti-pattern in the book. From brittle tests, over-mocked tests and everything in between.

Tests are supposed to improve maintainability, drive design decision and uncover code smells. Tests can do all these things, but only if we’re writing good tests. In this session, we’ll cover eight simple rules for writing good tests, from what to embrace and what to avoid. Nothing is sacred in this session, as I’ll cover all the ways I’ve failed with testing and where I find success in testing today.

Title: A .NET Developers Introduction to MongoDB
Abstract:
This talk will introduce developers to the MongoDB NoSQL platform and explain how it can be utilized as a robust data store alternative for your applications.   We will discuss the concept of NoSQL in general and will walk through the basics of MongoDB and include many demonstrations of reading and writing data to a MongoDB instance via the provided C# drivers.

Throughout this talk we will compare and contrast the MongoDB concepts with the patterns traditionally followed in relational database systems such as SQL Server or Oracle.   We will also share a significant amount of resources (books, blogs, links, courses, etc) that will make your adoption of MongoDB as easy as possible.

Title: A Bird's Eye View of ClojureScript
Abstract:
Birds travel thousands of miles each year to migrate, flying for hours on very little food and rest. By comparison, migrating databases seems like a paltry feat.

Birdwave is a way to visualize the amazing phenomenon of bird migration. Using ClojureScript and Om allowed the app to be written in a  declarative, concise manner, taking full advantage of JavaScript interoperability, as well as Clojure's awesome built-in features such as persistent data structures and the async module. Also, prepare to be dazzled by the data-viz powerhouse that is D3.

No birds were harmed in the creation of Birdwave. Or this talk.

App site: http://birdwave.neo.com

Related blog posts: http://www.neo.com/2014/04/21/choropleths-and-d3js, http://www.neo.com/2014/07/18/using-the-flickr-api-with-clojurescript

Title: A guided tour of the BigData technologies zoo
Abstract:
Elephants (named "Hadoop" after a toy), bees and hives, pigs, ELKs, rabbits and one ZooKeeper. You can find them in a zoo, or you are just a software developer trying to make sense out of data using technologies with weird names.

This session will be a guided tour of the BigData kingdom. We will explore various challenges one has to face when handling large volumes of data, and learn about various tools with funny names which were built to help in the process.

Equipped with real-world examples and use-cases, by the end of this session BigData should stop being a buzzword to you.

Title: Accessible Web Application development using ARIA
Abstract:
WAI-ARIA's role and aria-attributes, combined with the rich capabilities of JavaScript allow rich Internet applications to be made accessible without any limitations for disabled users. 

This session will explain the relationship between the DOM and the accessibility tree, give an overview of all the ARIA roles and attributes and how adding these to the DOM impacts the accessibility tree.

It will highlight the ARIA roles that work well across multiple platforms as well as the tricks necessary to get them to work consistently and cover 5 best practices for successfully implementing ARIA in a cross-platform fashion.

It will show an example of a gesture-and-keyboard compatible widget implemented using ARIA with annotated source code available for the attendees to get their hands dirty.

Title: Adapt your testing approach for agile
Abstract: Testing in an agile methodology is the responsibility of the whole team. So if you are in an agile team then this talk is for you. To produce good quality software repeatedly and at an ever increasing frequency, means we all (not just testers) need to adapt. Believe it or not you can’t just test faster, but you can make smarter choices. More often than not, you must automate but automation does not solve everything. More fundamental to improving the testing is the techniques you apply in determining what to test. How to test them comes second. This session will cover ways to adapt your approach and offer practical examples of techniques to use to identify the areas to test. It will also cover testing approaches that can then be applied to test the areas identified.

Title: Adventures Beyond the Page Fold - Exploring UX Mythology
Abstract: Too often does good UX design fall prey to “conventional wisdom” and an app or website is hijacked by stakeholders way too eager to believe theoretical nonsense, without any credible proof or even their own relevant experience. In this session, we will explore some of the more common pitfalls of UX mythology, from the legendary Adventures Beyond the Page Fold, to The 3 Clicks of Destiny, to The Faceted Navigation of Doom and more! We’ll look at each in turn and determine if each holds true or can be labeled as busted. There will be audience participation and prizes including the latest season of Myth Busters and a copy of Steve Krug’s, Rocket Surgery Made Easy. Armed with the truth, you will be able to reliably defend against the onslaught of poor UX, perpetrated by design-by-committee, and reach true UX harmony.

Title: Adventures in LINQ: party like it's 2007
Abstract:
Think you know LINQ? It's 2015, of course you do... at least, you probably know how to use it... so long as you stick to the standard operators, of course.
But how does it *really* work? What's lurking beneath the calm surface of lambda expressions?

LINQ may feel a bit retro now, with C# 6 on the horizon, but it's a fascinating topic to dig into... then dig further... and further.

Thrill to see query expressions converted into normal C#!
Swoon over the complex state machine generated by a simple iterator block!
Gasp at the nuances of optimizing lazily-evaluated sequences!
Rejoice as your own code extends LINQ to Objects seamlessly!

Title: An Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
Abstract: Ever want to know how computers think? In this session attendees will learn the foundations of artificial intelligence through a collaborative discussion centered around the creation of an intelligent game. Attendees will also learn how to use advanced search techniques to solve complex problems using specialized heuristics. In short, attendees will understand how to make intelligent programs by learning how to pose an AI problem in order to maximize desired outcomes.

Title: An Introduction to Rust
Abstract: Rust is a new systems programming language focused on safety and speed. This precompiler will give you a thorough understandings of the core ideas of Rust, and then move into the more complex parts. Afterward, you should have no problems writing your own Rust programs and libraries.

Title: Android TDD
Abstract: There's no reason why Agile practices and Android can't go hand in hand. In this class, learn how to add TDD (test driven development or unit tests) to your next Android project. Thankfully, you no longer have to rely on Google's Unit3 testing framework. The class begins with a look at what tools are available for Unit Testing, Mocking and Code Coverage from ActivityInstrumentationTestCase2 (jUnit3), Roboelectric (jUnit4) to Mockito and Dagger. We'll also create a sample app using Roboelectric and Dagger to show best practices for creating a Test Driven Environment.

Title: Angular for .NET Developers
Abstract: As software developers we should always be striving to give our users the best experience possible. It should be intuitive, responsive and above all fast! With traditional web technologies, creating applications that appear “fast” to the users can be difficult. To solve this problem developers have been finding new and creative ways to leverage the browsers client-side functionality. One of the most popular frameworks for creating a web application with powerful client-side front end functionality is Angular. Angular is a powerful client side data framework that lets you bind and manipulate data easily in a way that seems lightning fast to your users. And the best part is you don’t need to be a JavaScript ninja to use it! This session will show you how to leverage Angular with your ASP.NET MVC application to create applications that your users will love and you’ll love to build.

Title: Angular's Missing Guide: Build Anything With These 5 Concepts
Abstract:
AngularJS empowers developers by providing the means to rapidly create rich user experiences, but its API is massive and you're busy. This session teaches the 5 concepts that you need to get productive in Angular, fast:  ng-controller, ng-repeat, ng-model, ng-click, and filter. You'll then see how they're used together by exploring realistic and approachable code examples. 


Attendees will walk out of this session with the tools needed to ship engaging, interactive, websites.

Title: Are You Over-Testing?
Abstract: What is your code coverage? Why not 10% more or less? Is testing this feature more important than shipping the next? Many teams spend too much time and energy on testing the wrong things. In this session, an enterprise developer turned startup entrepreneur will dive into the costs and benefits of testing. You will learn about the organizational and social dynamics that drives teams to over-test. You will come away armed to convince your team, your manager, and your business to ship more and maximize test value. Check your dogma at the door and let's ship some valuable software.

Title: ASP.NET is Coming to an OSX Near You
Abstract: Do you wish you could use OSX for ASP.NET development? Interested in exploring the .NET web frameworks, but are adverse to installing Windows and Visual Studio? Do you judge Mono as a less-than-ideal port of the .NET framework? Everything has changed: ASP.NET isn’t just for Windows, anymore. Learn how ASP.NET has broken free from Windows and has turned into a cross-platform, OS-agnostic framework. Develop ASP.NET applications on your OS, with your editor, in your way. No more compromises, no VMs, no workarounds: ASP.NET is coming to an OSX near you.

Title: ASP.NET Performance Tips and Tricks
Abstract:
Out of the box, ASP.NET can do a lot of amazing things.  The tools and framework have grown to make mundane tasks, such as minification, simple to implement.  Many times by using the framework as we were taught, opportunities to optimize pass us by.  The reality is that underneath the covers, there is a whole world of easy tweaks we can implement to help ASP.NET perform at its peak.  

In this presentation, we will walk through a slew of tweaks used to make ASP.NET perform in the best way possible. You will leave with a checklist of tasks that will instantly improve the performance of your web application!

Title: Async JavaScript at Netflix
Abstract:
What's does a mouse drag event have in common with an Array of numbers?

The answer to this question may surprise you: they are both collections. This key insight holds the key to dramatically simplifying asynchronous programming in JavaScript. In this talk you will learn how you can use the familiar JavaScript Array methods to create surprisingly expressive asynchronous programs. Using just a few functions, you will learn how to do the following:
• Declaratively build complex events out of simple events (ex. drag n' drop)
• Coordinate and sequence multiple Ajax requests
• Reactively update UI's in response to data changes
• Eliminate memory leaks caused by neglecting to unsubscribe from events
• Gracefully propagate and handle asynchronous exception
 
In this talk we'll be exploring the Reactive Extensions (RxJS) library (http://github.com/reactive-extensions/RxJS), which allows us to treat events as collections. You'll learn about how Netflix uses Rx on the client and the server, allowing us to build end-to-end reactive systems. We'll also contrast Rx with Promises, another popular approach to building asynchronous programs in JavaScript.

Title: Asynchronous? Parallel? Reactive? Help!
Abstract:
The modern world of concurrency can certainly be confusing! This talk is a gentle introduction to the many forms of concurrency. In this talk, you'll learn which types of concurrency are appropriate for which scenarios.

Most developers have heard of parallelism, so this talk starts with parallel computing, showcasing the Parallel class and Parallel LINQ (PLINQ).

The next stop is asynchronous code. Asynchronous code is a totally different kind of concurrency than parallel processing, and the async and await keywords enable maintainable asynchronous code in modern applications.

This talk will also introduce you to TPL Dataflow. A beautiful mix of parallel and asynchronous techniques, TPL Dataflow is a little-known but extremely powerful library.

The last technology covered is Reactive Extensions. This talk will cover the concepts behind Rx and the most useful operators. This session is entirely practical; the phrase "mathematical dual of IEnumerable" does not appear on any slides.

Title: Attack of the clones: Eliminating duplicate code in .NET
Abstract: Code duplication threatens the agility and maintainability of software.  Literally repeated code can be easily remedied, but there are other more subtle and insidious kinds of code duplication.  What about code that's the same except for type, or code that needs to be applied in many locations?  In this session, you will learn about tools to help find duplicate code.  After identifying problem code, you will learn how to eradicate it with software design techniques and .NET framework features.  Specifically, you will see how to apply generics, delegates, extension methods, and attributes to quash repeated code. You will leave with ideas and techniques to reduce duplicated code in your development.

Title: Automated Testing and Processes for your iOS Agile Team
Abstract: Let’s explore how Continuous Integration combined with Automated Acceptance Testing can be integrated into an iOS Mobile Developer Team’s Agile process. The integration is intended to improve code quality and increase project margin. We will investigate how Apple Development build tools, combined with Objective-C/Swift Open Source projects, combined with Jenkins CI, can make an iOS Native Mobile Developer’s dream setup come true. We’ll show how when you combine all this, you can release faster, strong and more often.  Bring your own Mac and Xcode. Slides, sample code, and fun will be provided. Be sure you're registered for Github too.

Title: Automating Visual Studio
Abstract: The automation story for Visual Studio reads something like a Greek tragedy: mechanisms for automation have born and died, and none of them have been terribly effective.  However, over the last few years the story has changed.  Come learn how to drive Visual Studio from technologies you already use, such as NuGet packages and the package manager console.  You’ll be delighted and inspired by the demos, which include scripting out project creation and configuration, adding custom menu items across the IDE, and a data-driven refactoring of code.  Warning: attending this session will absolutely change the way you use Visual Studio – for the better!

Title: Automating Your Azure Environment
Abstract: Like most things in life, there’s the easy way and the hard way.  The same holds when working in cloud environments such as Microsoft Azure.  The Azure management portal and Visual Studio can be great for those relatively simple projects, but quickly become very tedious when trying to create the multiple re-sources that often make up a real-world solution.  In this session, we’ll demonstrate how to leverage various tools such as PowerShell, Azure Resource Manager, Azure Automation, and the Azure Management Library to quickly and consistently create full environments in minutes.

Title: Automotive Android
Abstract:
Over the last year, many Automotive companies have released SDKs and APIs and Google have announced Automotive Android that finally allow Android developers to create their own mobile automotive apps that expand the boundaries of the automotive dashboard far beyond the physical car. 

In this class, you'll learn how to create apps for this new and relatively overlooked commercial opportunity for mobile developers. We'll also build a couple of sample apps that focus on how communicate with Ford's Sync and GM's Remote APIs .

Title: Be proactive, use reactive!
Abstract:
Today‘s apps contain a lot of moving parts, and juggling this complexity is what makes or breaks the user experience. In order to keep our sanity and reduce the amount of bugs that get shipped, we need to raise our level of abstraction.

ReactiveCocoa (RAC) is a framework that brings the (functional) reactive programming world into the grossly imperative land of iOS. It builds off of Cocoa's own key-value observing mechanism to provide a high-level, declarative API for composing operations on streams of data, state, and asynchronous tasks. You’ll leave this session with a solid foundation of RAC and how one can apply it in conjunction with powerful tools like MVVM to build applications.

Title: Being RDBMS Free
Abstract: The general thinking is that when you create a new application, your data will be persisted into an RDBMS like SQL Server. But with the advent of NoSQL solutions, document databases, key-value stores and other options, do you really need an RDBMS for your application? In this session we’ll look at some alternatives to your persistence solution by looking at utilizing NoSQL solutions like Mongo, search services like Solr, key-value stores and other approaches to data persistence. By the end of this session, you’ll rethink how your applications will store data in the future.

Title: Better Code, Better Debugging
Abstract: Our platforms and development environments keep offering better debugging support, but debugging is still a game of strategy. It’s a critical game because we fix bugs from the time we first check in code, and the cost of each bug tends to increase across the project lifecycle. Come to this talk to merge strategy with the debugging tools in your environment. In the examples, you’ll see debugging features in the current version of Visual Studio and upcoming in Visual Studio “14,” along with Windows features like ETW (Event Tracing for Windows). Good debugging strategies let you ask better questions and tools offer an array of tactics to efficiently answer most questions.  Strategies and tactics differ a bit depending on the difficulty of the bug and where you can reproduce it. If it occurs only in production and remote debugging is not possible in your scenario, you’ll debug through piles of information. Find out what Windows can provide for you, without changing your application, and small changes to your application that increase the value of this information. Leave this talk ready to formulate ideas into testable strategies you can execute to resolve bugs faster and with more confidence.

Title: Beyond UI Frameworks: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly
Abstract: UI frameworks like Bootstrap or Foundation have a lot of perks: cross-browser consistency, ease-of-use, and visual design standards to name a few. However, they can be difficult to integrate into existing web applications in organizations with specific UI/UX vision. In this session, we will discuss our use case of building a custom UI framework named CoreUI at OCLC while working on WorldCat.org and WorldCat for local institutions. We will show the good (why and how we built it), the bad (roadblocks and traps to avoid), and the ugly (convincing a large organization) of building a custom framework. Attendees will get insight into our process, cross-disciplined approach and tools we used to build a true UI style guide; not just a UI framework. We will share concrete examples of how we built strict guidelines yet a flexible framework, maintained an encapsulated, non-intrusive code base and ensured code quality with builds, and produced a tiny framework size in the end.

Title: Break It Before You Buy It - Hacking and Fixing Web Applications
Abstract: As developers, we focus on the utility and usability of the systems we build, as we should. There is another consideration, though, and that is the criminal element and its access to our systems. The most utile and usable system is dangerous to deploy without appropriate security controls in place. In this four hour bootcamp, you'll get a look at the security principles that will keep your systems more secure, learn to test for specific vulnerabilities, and put your new skills on the line using Burp Suite in a Capture The Flag competition that will run the entirety of CodeMash. The session will cover Authentication and Content Management, Injection Vulnerabilities, Cracking and Fixing REST APIs, and Data Security. This is a hands on session, so make sure to download the Virtual Machine at CodeMashCTF.com, or from the CodeMash FTP Server.

Title: Build Right: Frontend Testing
Abstract:
Frontend projects are becoming more and more complex, pushing greater rules and requirements into the browser. We expect a lot from modern web applications (many run entirely in the browser), but we’re rarely writing tests to verify that our high expectations are met.

Come explore the magical world of Frontend Testing with the Sparkbox team. Together we will examine the pain points of developing without tests and look at some of our real-world examples. We’ll also talk about what you should and shouldn't test, and get our hands dirty with...

- Jasmine / CoffeeScript
- Automating tests in the build process
- Adding tests to existing code
- Refactoring jQuery spaghetti
- Handling AJAX requests and Promises
- Coding for better tests
- Running tests in a CI build

Prepare to receive the tools and techniques to build solid, tested frontend code. And don't worry—we'll talk about selling the concept to your team back home and gradually work it into your process.

Title: Building Code Aware Frameworks using the .NET Compiler Platform (“Roslyn”)
Abstract: Now that you’ve seen how to take advantage of what’s new in C# as a consumer, come learn how to leverage the .NET Compiler Platform to transform your library into Code Aware Framework.  This session will demonstrate how to help users of your library avoid common misuses of your API by implementing a user diagnostic which runs as part of the compilation process for anyone who references your NuGet package and is reported live in Visual Studio.  Next we’ll extend the VS “14” experience with an automated fix to get your users back on track.  If you develop library code for .NET, either public or for your own company, come see how to take them to the next level by turning them into Code Aware Frameworks.

Title: Building Custom node.js Modules
Abstract:
The growth of node.js can solely be placed on it's community, and their ability to develop modules when a need arises. Developers constantly see ways they can abstract their code bases out into individual modules, which node.js has fantastic support for. In this presentation, Kevin Griffin will guide attendees through the process of creating a node module and distributing it in the Node Package Manager central repository.

Learning Objectives

Attendees will learn what the Node Package Manager and public vs private repositories.
Attendees will learn how to develop their own node modules and how use them in their applications.
Attendees will learn how to upload their modules to the central NPM database for public consumption.

Title: Building DSLs using JavaScript/CoffeeScript
Abstract:
Web developers are integration specialists; tying plugins, scripts and frameworks together into a web application that works. Thinking in terms of abstractions, by condensing many low-level ideas into fewer high-level ideas, allows us to simplify our code and reason about it with less cognitive overhead.

In this session we will examine a few techniques for building abstractions on top of popular JavaScript frameworks by building a Domain Specific Language and bringing some convention to our code.

Title: Building Highly Scalable Apps on the Azure Platform:  Real World Guidance
Abstract:
While many talks provide a high level overview of a few components of the Azure platform, this session will provide real-world examples of how we utilize Azure on real-world, highly scalable applications.

Key areas we will demonstrate and discuss include:

•	General scalability and moving a heavy amount of workload off the web servers
•	Using the Azure Service Bus to communicate between our front-end web servers and our back-end worker roles
•	 Azure’s caching options and how we utilize them to serve a significant amount of data to clients out of memory and to support things such as ASP.NET Session State.
•	Using Blob Storage as an effectively unlimited amount of file storage.
•	Our usage of newer features such as the scheduler, mobile notifications, and auto scaling.
•	Our development and deployment process surrounding Azure based applications

This session, while only an hour long, will walk through a lot of code and tooling to show how we have leaned on Azure to solve a number of architectural headaches.

If you are using (or considering using) Azure as the foundation for your own applications, this session would be a great place to get ideas on where you should start.

Title: Building the Internet of Things... with JavaScript?
Abstract: The internet of things revolution is coming.  Are you ready for the onslaught of smart devices that is right around the corner?  As developers, the more important question is, are you ready to be a part of contributing to the internet of things?  The barrier to entry is now lower than ever - the Tessel board from Technical Machine (tessel.io) allows you to control hardware with JavaScript running in node.js on the embedded chip!  Yeah - JavaScript.  In this session, I'll give you an overview of the Tessel board and many of the modules available to build the next generation of smart devices.  You'll be surprised how easy it is.

Title: Building with Web Accessibility in Mind
Abstract:
Building web applications so that they are accessible to people with disabilities is easy. Yet many web developers don't spend the extra time to do it right. It is estimated that as many as one in five people have some sort of disability or impairment. Regardless of the purpose of the application this is essential to consider.

This session will include an in-depth discussion of web accessibility guidelines and standards following the WCAG 2.0 specification.  It will also focus on a how-to for actually implementing these guidelines and building them into the UI of any web-based application. The web developer that is already skilled in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, will learn practical coding techniques to make their applications accessible to all.

Title: Building Your First Android Wear App
Abstract: With the introduction of Google's Android Wear, you are no longer restricted to just phones and tablets when it comes to developing great Android apps. You want notifications on your wrist? You got it. You want to run an app on your wrist? You got it. In this session, let me take you through the awesome new features of Android Wear and the tools required to start building the apps you want for Wear. We'll extend a current app with rich notifications and even create a brand new app from scratch live on stage that runs right on your Android Wear device. All demonstrations will be coded in C#, but will be applicable to any Android developer in any language.

Title: Bulletproof Android
Abstract: This session takes a look at Android security from a developer rather than a hacker's perspective.  Taken from the soon to be published book Bulletproof Android, we look at how to protect your Android code, how to use secure authentication in your app, how to communicate securely with any backend server and how to safeguard that server against attack. Throughout the session we'll use real world examples from the many audits we've done over the years to show how other developers have tried and sometimes failed to secure their code.

Title: Business Scale Rails with Docker
Abstract:
In recent years, most Rails developers have usually used go-to services for going from git push to code being on production. As developers and operations staff we sometimes find ourselves with infrastructure and code bases growing under our feet and in our sleep and sometimes managed services stop meeting the needs of a business or project. 

Once your business grows to the point where you have dedicated Sales, QA, and Growth departments, how do you manage to keep all the environments for everyone in check? When your bundling and asset compilation takes 30 minutes, how do you get hot fixes out in any reasonable amount of time? When your dev staff is distributed, how can you ensure everyone has access to the proper environment, and more importantly, that they don't have potentially destructive powers in places they shouldn't?

We've struggled with each of these questions, and after a lot of trial and error, ended up on a Docker based build and deploy system that accelerated our build times, time through CI, QA deploys, and general time to production with little to no downtime. We've also been able to deploy the same applications for demo use offline, quickly scale applications in the case of emergency, provide developer safe security, and a whole lot more

In this talk we'll talk about Rails-specific practices for building your app into a Docker image and what benefits you get immediately from that alone. Then we'll talk about how you can use that image through the rest of your dev process cycle to get the ease of use of a managed service with the freedom to use your container as you please.

Title: BYOD : build your own drone... multi-rotor copter that is !
Abstract:
In this world of ever increasing opportunities to purchase 'toys' classified as 'drones'... have you ever wanted to fly a drone?  Have you ever asked yourself the question... should I buy a drone or build?

This presentation will discuss why the term 'drone' should be most generally referred to as... 'multi-rotor copter' and not UAV (unmanned autonomous vehicle) or drone.  

This presentation will discuss the basics of how a multi-rotor works... the steps to build a multi-rotor... including details on flight controllers, frame selection, motors and props (including determining what type of multi-rotor will suite your purpose), speed controllers and batteries.  There are a lot of variables... all of these details will be broken down, making the process of building your first copter a 'flight in the park'.

At the end... a flying multi-rotor copter will be air-worthy and demonstrated.

Title: Callback-free concurrency: Elixir vs. Node
Abstract: Tired of callback hell and fighting with the event loop? Node.js is a popular choice for building real-time applications, but it comes with some serious drawbacks. Elixir, a new functional language targeting the Erlang VM,  promises to combine the stability and scalability of Erlang with the expressiveness of Ruby. In this session, two implementations of the same real-time application will be compared: one written in Node.js and one written in Elixir. You will learn how Node and Elixir solve the same problems in very different ways, and see how Elixir enables massive concurrency and fault tolerance with code that is callback-free, concise, testable, and easy to reason about.

Title: Changing the Testing Culture
Abstract:
Testing is often seen as an uninteresting, boring and mundane activity done by unskilled people; why is this? Why have I found it difficult to explain to a lay person what my job is? Being able to explain testing in an interesting way and how it’s rewarding and challenging is a difficult task. The main issue, as I see it, is that testing is not a recognised career choice; most people drop in to testing and either stay or move on. 

How do we get people to see that testing is a rewarding and challenging career choice? From my experience of over seventeen years, I've encountered a varied collection of opinions about testing and testers; a significant number have been negative. 

To change these negative opinions of what testing and testers are we need to change the culture within our workspace. By reframing testing as a science and constantly challenging status quo ideas that others may have of testing is a powerful way to start the evolution from testing as a role to testing as an activity that everyone is involved with. Thereby changing from testing at the end of a broken chain to one whereby testing is done throughout the development process.
 
Considering testing as a science and explaining how you approach testing using the scientific method, in my experience, helps significantly with this paradigm shift. Testing is a science, and just like science, testers often don't have all the information and have to use their curiosity, imagination, intuition and experience of the world to find problems so that users don’t.

Changing the language, from one with words like pass, coverage, test cases and move towards talking about what you know to be true now, based on evidence and experiments. Don't assume, never say never or other definitive words. Correct others appropriately when they say things like always, I'm sure it will, definitely, must, should, yeah of course it'll do that.

In my experience, these two simple changes have worked to improve people’s opinions of testers and testing. I will be using specific examples that I have experienced to show how I have used these and other approaches to change the cultural opinion of testing.

Title: Chat Robots Next Level Tooling
Abstract:
**Developers are lazy!** So we are great in creating tooling for our daily work. But it has its weaknesses, we are creating a tons of scripts on our local machine, sometimes we share them via git or other vcs systems. But all over all this tooling sucks when it comes to collaboration. We developers also love hanging out in chat rooms like campfire or jabber.

Why not combine this via chat robots. Our tooling would be available to everyone without installing wired shell scripts plus we can get rid if questions like: `“Do you have the deploy lock?”` or `“Did you already migrate the database?”` - it’s all documented in the transcripts.

I’d like to talk about how to improve your daily work with [hubot](http://hubot.github.com/), a chat robot build by the fine folks at github.

Title: Clean Code: Writing Code for Humans
Abstract:
Anyone can write code a computer can understand, but professional developers write code *humans* can understand. This session discusses best practices for writing code in a style that’s easy to create, maintain and understand. We have a lofty goal: programming style as documentation. We’ll discuss concrete methods to get you there and give you a vocabulary for pragmatically evaluating code quality.
Various refactoring techniques, code smells, best practices are discussed including fail fast, return early, arrow code, being “stringly typed”, the outline rule, and table-driven methods. Part of this session involves refactoring a confusing and ugly chunk of code into something beautiful, easy to read and maintain. While examples are in C#, coders in any language should be able to follow along and apply the principles discussed.

Title: Coming up to speed on Swift
Abstract: Discover Swift, the new programming language from Apple. By examining and modifying a real iOS app, learn how it compares and contrasts with more established languages like JavaScript, C#, Python, and Objective-C.  Begin the journey towards mastering Swift; seize on its possibilities and avoid its pitfalls.

Title: Composing a Compiler
Abstract:
Composition is powerful. Consider any artistic endeavor; any style of music, art, photography, etc. Creativity thrives on composition. The bringing together of various elements into a complementary whole. Carefully selected, simple pieces assembled with skill and insight can yield breathtaking complexity and beauty.

Yet composition s not widely used as a paradigm in creating software today. While it sounds nice in theory to write small, simple, and correct pieces of code and then plug them together, there is little in the way of practical examples to show how it's done. With practice, designing for composition can become second nature.

This talk will use the problem of writing a Clojure-to-C compiler as an example. A full explanation of the process, with code, will demonstrate how to accomplish this in Clojure while the concepts will be applicable to any functional programming language.

Title: Concurrency for !Dummies (Who Don't Get It (...Yet))
Abstract: You can't go to a Ruby conference lately without someone banging on about concurrency and thread safety. You're a smart Rubyist, but... you don't get it. You understand the basic idea, you nod along, but once they get into the jargon, what does it all mean? How does it apply to you, and what is it, exactly? This talk will answer those questions, by engaging in a basic primer on concurrency in Ruby, a discussion of actual examples of how it works, and provide you with answers that will leave you nodding in agreement, rather than nodding off.

Title: Connecting C# to Arduino and the world outside your computer
Abstract: C# is a great language, but our C# code is confined inside of our computers. What do we do if we want to control a motor or display information on an analog gage? We can use the C#, ScriptCs and the ScriptCS-Arduino library to interface with the world outside of the computer. In this session you will learn how to get started.

Title: Consuming Data with F#'s Type Providers
Abstract: Have you ever needed to access a data source in your application? Trick question! Are there developers who would answer no to that question? Of course not! Join me and I'll walk you through just how quick and easy data access can be with F#'s new Type Providers. I'll cover connecting to several different data sources using the relevant type providers, as well as when and how to write your own. Before we part, you'll be on your way to type provider mastery!

Title: Control your computer with your Brain!
Abstract: In this session we'll explore the OpenBCI (Open Brain Computer Interface), Arduino compatible, board. This board allows sampling of brain activity (EEG). Using these samples, we can make use of them for control of other devices.

Title: Covering Your PAAS :  Securing Azure Platform As A Service Offerings
Abstract:
Just because you get your Platform As A Service, doesn't mean you get a free pass on security.  Sure, lots has been done to make sure you fall into the pit of success. We will start with securing Azure Websites, and move to Blob Storage, Service Bus, and Databases.

All of the Demo's and descriptions in this talk should be highly accessible to all, even if you've never given cloud security a thought. You will walk away with some very quick and easy to implement steps to secure your Azure PAAS apps.

Title: Creating J.A.R.V.I.S. - An Awesome Guide To Automating Your Home
Abstract:
A few years ago I gave one of my robots the job of turning on and off the lights based on sunrise/sunset. Later that years I added a little more functionality by asking it what I should wear everyday (shorts/jeans) based on the weather forecast. In 2014 I now have a dedicated server monitoring 9 network cameras for motion detection and performing face recognition, controlling TVs, thermostats, stereos, the coffee machine and many more things. I can even call my house on Skype to get statuses or tell it what to do.

In this talk I'll give an overview of all the modern systems used to control household appliances and lights. I'll give an overview of products with useful REST APIs and how to roll-your-own with a Raspberry PI and a a few inexpensive sensors. I'll also show you how I've built my own J.A.R.V.I.S. and give you an overview of the code and equipment for you to do the same.

As a bonus bring a new robot to the talk and show you how J.A.R.V.I.S. communicates with this robot and tells it what to do. Yes computers commanding robots without human input.

Title: Cross-Platform Mobile Development with C#
Abstract:
This is an introductory session to Cross-Platform Mobile Development using C# with Xamarin's tools.  We will cover the basics of cross-platform mobile development with Xamarin, including a discussion of what you CAN and CAN'T do, the business case for using Xamarin instead of native development, and the different approaches to code-sharing that Xamarin provides.

If you're a .NET developer interested in breaking into Mobile, or have heard of Xamarin but want to know if it's really as good as it sounds, this is the session for you.

Title: Cucumber Ain't Bad, You Are Just Doing It Wrong
Abstract:
The cry from developers is unanimous: "I don't like Cucumber, my acceptance tests are brittle and hard to maintain!" And in fact, they can be.
I'll show you in this talk what tools and techniques you should use to write independent, stateless step definitions that can be weaved together to form a testing DSL.

Title: Data Science for Fun and Profit
Abstract: Make no mistake, data science can be hard, but it can also be fun. In this session I'll introduce you to Classic and Bayesian Statistics and Machine Learning, all through the medium of predicting horse racing results. We'll explore a number of techniques for making such predictions and finish by combining them into a powerful "mixed model" prediction engine that's sure to pick the next big winner. This session won't only improve your knowledge, it'll improve your bank balance too! Note: probably won't do the latter though. :-)

Title: Debugging with Xcode
Abstract: This intermediate level session will help you get more out of debugging with Xcode. It will start with the basics, like logging, breakpoints and variables, and move to more advanced topics like conditional breakpoints, watching memory and location debugging.

Title: Deconstructing Single Page Applications
Abstract: The modern web has introduced new demands for performance that cannot be met solely on the server side, and Single Page Applications (SPAs) have rushed in to meet those demands. The SPA universe is full of choices (Backbone, Angular, Ember and more).  What sets them apart, and how do you choose one?  They all address the same problem set: rendering, routing, data-binding, event handling, composability and others.  By dissecting how different frameworks approach these problems, we can investigate the quirks that set frameworks apart and gain a more intimate understanding of the SPA architecture itself.  For beginners, ninjas and anyone in between, this talk can guide you further in the search for SPA enlightenment.

Title: Decoupling the Frontend through Modular CSS
Abstract:
CSS is hard. It’s a simple language, but getting it right and avoiding specificity hell can be a challenge if you don’t have the right framework to back you up.  Especially in large scaling projects, you might start adding ID selectors here and !important properties there and the next thing you know you’ve backed yourself into a corner where even the smallest of UI changes will take hours to work out. Ew.

Or how about this? Ever jump into a project and find that even the slightest markup change results in broken JavaScript AND sometimes even broken backend feature tests?! WTF. Ew.

This talk will look at how taking a modular, object-oriented approach to CSS can turn frontend woes into frontend wins. We’ll examine modern CSS approaches like OOCSS, SMACSS, and BEM and demonstrate how they will help to not only decouple your CSS styles and reduce specificity conflicts, but how they will also help to decouple your CSS and HTML from your JavaScript and feature specs.

Title: Defense in Depth with AOP
Abstract:
Web application security has never been harder.  Our adversary is cunning and clever, and with software becoming more and more complex its harder than ever to ensure security.  This presentation is about using Aspect Oriented Programming to help organize our code in a way that makes implementing security practices easier, centrally maintained and helps to bring security to the forefront of the software development process.  Our aim is to slow or stop our attackers on multiple levels using AOP as our mechanism for achieving this.   

Code for this talk will be in C# with PostSharp however the concepts can be applied to virtually any programming language or AOP tool.

Title: Defensible application architecture
Abstract: Every application we build is subject to attack. Every data item we store is subject to theft. And with most everything delivered by mobile and the Web, traditional network security devices cannot protect our code. This session will cover the patterns and practices for developing defensible applications; including code hardening, security logging, user stories for security operations, and embedding security throughout the development life cycle. Our code will be attacked. Let’s be ready.

Title: Deploying all day without breaking the Internet
Abstract:
At Bitly we serve over 6 billion clicks/per month, record each one, and do all sorts of analysis on that data to provide useful information back to our users.

As a company we face two major challenges:
  1.  Not breaking the Internet - if Bitly links stop working, a non-trivial part of the Internet just became much less useful.
  2.  Moving fast - we need to continually adapt to change and build new tools to provide more value to our users.

This presents the eternal challenge of accomplishing both stability and speed.   This talk will cover the processes, approaches, and tools used to do over 20-30 deploys each day to over 400 servers without causing any major disruptions to service.

Some of the topics to be covered include:
  * Benefits of Service Oriented Architecture
  * Designing with ops in mind from day one
  * The power of NSQ (realtime distributed messaging)
  * Asynchronous > Synchronous (except when it isn't)
  * Designing for predictability
  * Route around failure (via hostpool)
  * Automate + Monitor ALL THE THINGS
  * Peer review for code + process

Title: Develop a Cross-Platform 2D Game: Hands-on Workshop
Abstract:
You know you want to create a game like Angry Birds that allows you to fling your manager's head into boiling lava!  With only a laptop running Windows and an HTML-5 capable browser, you can create wicked-cool games for iOS, Android, and Windows.  Start from scratch or build on templates to create shooters, platformers, side-runners, physics puzzles, driving games, and more without having to code your own physics engine.  In this workshop, beginning and experienced developers alike will learn Construct 2 (from Scirra) with plenty of hands-on time to build a compelling, addictive game!  

Under the covers, this tool uses HTML5 and JavaScript.  This makes it easy and fun for beginners to create games, and more advanced developers can rapidly prototype games and dive into the underlying HTML5 and JavaScript.  

Please bring a laptop running Windows with an HTML5-capable browser.

Title: Developer Flow: Harness the Power of Flow for Happier Developers
Abstract: Developers are ‘makers’. We like to get things done. The more productive we are, the happier we are. This connection between productivity and happiness has been researched in the field of positive psychology as flow: the theory that people are happiest when they are in a state of absorption with an activity, or in the zone (credit: M. Csiksgentmihalyi). Using LEGOs and other interactive exercises, this session will present how to effectively harness the power of flow to improve happiness while also producing high-quality deliverables. Participants will explore specific practices such as personal Kanban, the Pomodoro technique, and Test Driven Development.

Title: DevOps: What it is, What it Isn't, and Why Coders Should Care
Abstract:
DevOps is a lot of things.  It’s also not a lot of things, and the differences can lead to confusion and incorrect assumptions.  DevOps is related to Agile, but it’s not the same thing as Agile.  It needs tools, but the tools are just a part of the story.  DevOps is a cultural shift, a methodology, an operational philosophy, and a metaphor for software delivery.  It’s only about five years old, so it’s still toddling around development teams, management meetings, and executive boardrooms, attracting attention with every conversation.  The DevOps meme is about to go hype-rsonic, as Agile did about ten years ago.  When that happens, you’ll want to have a good idea what it is, what is isn’t, and why you and your company should care.
	This presentation will cut through the hype and boil DevOps down to its bare essentials.  I’ll talk about what DevOps is and the value it offers.  I’ll dispel a few common myths, and demonstrate resources for supporting DevOps Transformation in your organization.  DevOps means different things to different people, so we’ll talk about how to communicate DevOps concepts to various enterprise stakeholders.  When we’re done, you’ll be empowered to go out into the world and talk about DevOps, and maybe even help make it happen at your company.

Title: Discover your Inner Polyglot on the Google Cloud Platform
Abstract: The name Google is almost synonymous with large scale web applications. The Google software stack runs many of their popular applications such as Maps and GMail. Most small businesses and development shops can’t dream about being able to have access to anything like it … until now!  The Google Cloud Platform has everything a large scale web app could need.  Google App Engine gives developers a platform to deploy applications based on managed services using multiple languages.  For those who need more control, Google Compute Engine offers bare virtual machines.  Google Cloud Datastore, Cloud Storage and Cloud SQL provide an array of storage options.  If you’re looking for a better way to write web applications and services, learn more about the Google Cloud Platform.

Title: Docker – Introduction to Lightweight Virtualization
Abstract: Google is on board with Docker. As is IBM, Red Hat, and Amazon. Even Microsoft has joined the crew! What is Docker, why is it making a big splash in the developer community and how can it make your life easier? Come to this session and find out!

Title: ECMAScript 6 Now
Abstract: ECMAScript most famous dialect is JavaScript, and the coming version is ECMAScript 6 (ES6). Browsers already started supporting some of its features. JS programmers need to start learning about the coming changes. The presentation will show some of ES6 most useful features like classes, block scope, collections, proxies, arrow functions, iterators, generators, comprehensions, and modules. We will concentrate on the practical aspects of the changes. The session will be interactive, includes many code examples, and will encourage audience participation. By the end of the presentation, participants will know when and how to use ES6 in their own projects.

Title: Effective Data Visualization
Abstract:
We spend much of our time collecting and analyzing data. That data is only useful if it can be displayed in a meaningful, understandable way.
Yale professor Edward Tufte presented many ideas on how to effectively present data to an audience or end user. 
In this session, I will explain some of Tufte's most important guidelines about data visualization and how you can apply those guidelines to your own data. You will learn what to include, what to remove, and what to avoid in your charts, graphs, maps and other images that represent data.

Title: ElasticSearch - Distributed search and analytics on BigData made easy
Abstract: Elasticsearch is a cloud-ready, super scalable search engine which is gaining a lot of popularity lately. It is mostly known for being extremely easy to setup and integrate with any technology stack.In this talk we will introduce Elasticdearch, and start by looking at some of its basic capabilities. We will demonstrate how it can be used for document search and even log analytics for DevOps and distributed debugging, and peek into more advanced usages like the real-time aggregations and percolation. Obviously, we will make sure to demonstrate how Elasticsearch can be scaled out easily to work on a distributed architecture and handle pretty much any load.

Title: Elixir = Ruby, A Pattern Matching
Abstract:
Object-oriented programmers can have a dogmatic approach to language patterns. Whether it is analyzing, debating or criticizing various implementations, the passion for patterns emerges from the need to both communicate intent and categorize code. The patterns do more than define code, they describe it. So, what happens when we lose objects? When state fades away? When paradigms shift far more than a change in languages?

In steps Elixir. With syntax similar to Ruby but firmly grounded in the functional paradigm, it represents an easy transition for Rubyist into functional programming. But what about the beloved patterns? It turns out that understanding how functional languages implement some of the common object-oriented patterns can demystify this new paradigm. Plus learning new functional patterns can provide new solutions to old problems.

Title: Elixir For The Impatient
Abstract: Elixir is a functional programming language on top of the Erlang VM. It has the power of Erlang but in a modern, elegant, and beautiful form. Elixir makes it easy to write highly distributed systems in a reliable and scalable manner. This presentation will introduce the language and the tools to let you immediately write Elixir programs. Concepts introduced include modules, control and data structures, pattern matching, recursions, pipes (really cool), functional operations, and distributed messaging. We will avoid the classic functional jargon and concentrate on the productive side of the language. While showing these concepts, we will use the repl, the build tool, and unit testing. The session will include many pre-written code examples and will encourage audience participation. By the end of the presentation, it is hoped that you will be as excited about the language as the the presenter is.

Title: Elixir is for Rubyists
Abstract:
You keep hearing about this Elixir thing. "It's functional, meta-programmable, concurrent, and AWESOME!" they exclaim. I don't know who *they* are, but they're totally right.

As a long-time Rubyist, I've come to believe that Elixir has been artisianally crafted to suit the Rubyist's discriminating taste. We'll examine how Elixir's features and philosophy make it uniquely suited to complement the Rubyist's toolbelt, and how it might just change the way you think about solving problems.

Title: Engineering Innovation
Abstract:
Where do good ideas come from and how do we track them? Can we prioritize them and who gets to work on which idea?

Engineering teams obsess over how we manage the work of today and provide valuable feedback on the development process: Why are we building this feature? When will that feature be completed? What portions of the code changed in order to support this feature? These same teams rarely focus on the big ideas of tomorrow, even though in this information age most of what a company will do tomorrow is led by engineering.

Innovation happens best with small teams and structure, so like automated testing and builds, let's apply the same systemization to improvements and ideas so that the very best potential innovations are always at the forefront, and the best people are able to work on them at any point in time.

Title: Ethics and Effective A/B Testing
Abstract:
Facebook and OK Cupid have recently been under public scrutiny for the experiments they run on their users. The truth is every web site of a considerable enough scale experiments on their users. Whether it's searching for just the right shade of blue for the "Buy!" button or trying out a new algorithm to perfect the news feed, these are psychological experiments and the user is the subject.

In this talk, you'll be introduced to the basics of solid, overlapping, multivariate testing as well as a simple tool for enabling those experiments. This will enable you to perform more, better, safer experimentation. This talk will also include a healthy discussion on the ethics of experimentation to help steer you away from any possible controversy.

Title: Everything I Know About Design I Learned from Comics
Abstract:
Pow! Splatt! Boom! When most people think of comics they think of larger than life heroes or over the top cartoon characters. But what makes these big ideas work? It’s the spaces in between--the details that tie all the elements together, make the big moments gigantic, and the special moments memorable.

It’s the same with design. Whether you’re wireframing an app or building a corporate website, the design is the story you tell. 

You’ve already learned everything you need to know to about user centered design from comics. Brad will guide you through the basics and explain how design can tell the big stories, the little stories, and everything in between.

Title: Exploratory Testing for Everybody!
Abstract: Bring your laptop to this hands-on session of doing exploratory testing - a customer-value-centric style of testing that does not require boring paperwork (yet can still stand up to scrutinty.) Instead of planning the work and working the plan, Exploratory testing combines  test design, execution, reporting and learning in a simultaneous process. Done well it  can be a powerful tool in any team member's arsenal. Done poorly, ET can create confusion without adding much value. Learning by doing, we'l pair with a buddy, hear a little theory, and then get to testing. We'll have some more theory, then test a second application, then a third - then conduct a retrospective to talk about how these techniques can combine to improve coverage of the application, reducing time-to-done, and allow teams to compress testing into iterations, sprints, and other timeboxes.

Title: F# and Machine Learning: a Winning Combination
Abstract:
While Machine Learning practitioners routinely use a wide range of tools and languages, C# is conspicuously absent from that arsenal. Is .NET inadequate for Machine Learning? In this talk, I'll argue that it can be a great fit, as long as you use the right language for the job, namely F#.
F# is a functional-first language, with a concise and expressive syntax that will feel familiar to data scientists used to Python or Matlab. It combines the performance and maintainability benefits of statically typed languages, with the flexibility of Type Providers, a unique mechanism that enables seamless consumption of virtually any data source. And as a first-class .NET citizen, it interops smoothly with C#. So if you are interested in a language that can handle both flexible data exploration and the pressure of a real production system, come check out what F# has to offer.

Title: F# for the C# Developer
Abstract:
You have been writing C# for years, and are happy with it - so why bother with F#? 
This talk will compare and contrast F# and C# with live coding examples, illustrating why F# is an awesome language, where it shines, and how it fits. So if you are open to the idea that C# might not be the one and only solution to all your coding problems, or if you are simply tired of null reference exceptions, come check out what F# has to offer, and how it beautifully complements C#!

Title: F# in social gaming
Abstract:
F# is an incredibly versatile and expressive language and enables you to solve a wide array of problems succinctly and efficiently. This talk illustrates, with real-world examples, how the Gamesys social team uses F# to build the backend services that support around 1 million Daily Active Users (DAU) and 250 million daily requests across its social games on both mobile and web platforms.

Talk objectives:

- Demonstrate the use of F# to write clean, concise game logic as well as infrastructure code, the same techniques and concepts can be easily applied to other domains;

- Demonstrate how F# can help tackle recurring business problems of:

Efficiency
Correctness
Complexity
Time to Market

Title: Fantastic JVM Languages and Where to Find Them
Abstract: When Java came on to the scene, it changed everything…. Now almost 20 years later, while the language starts to show its age, the platform continues to be as fertile as ever. The JVM is the core of this ecosystem and everyday more languages are emerging from it. Scala, Clojure, Groovy, Jython, Jruby, Ceylon, XTrend… the list goes on and on. With all these languages to choose from, how do programmers decide which languages are right for the job? In this session, you’ll learn about some of these popular JVM languages, and explore how to choose the right language to fit your needs.

Title: Fostering Collaboration with Pattern Libraries and Rapid Prototyping
Abstract:
Recognize the benefits of using a living pattern library and rapid prototyping to increase communication and collaboration between designers and developers. In this session we will review a case study from an enterprise-level development group traditionally staffed with 60+ developers and no designers and how they were able to implement a pattern library and rapid prototyping framework into their design and development process. In this session we will discuss:

• recognizing patterns
• modular pattern creation
• how patterns can be combined to be used during rapid prototyping
• developing a consistent language that can be used between designers and developers

Title: From Backbone to Ember and Back(bone) Again
Abstract:
As a software consultant, I get to see a lot of interesting code. In this particular instance a client was in the process of transforming their web application to a rich, interactive interface with the help of another company.

The project kicked off using Backbone and things were great. Until they were not great. Pages starting getting more and more involved and blame started being thrown at the technology choice.

A move to Ember.js ensued and the app was rewritten. But architecturally bad decisions don't hide long, and soon the rewrite was preforming even worse.

That's when I stepped in, with the help of another consultant, to solve the performance issues once and for all. Our solution used Backbone.js and it was fast. This is that journey.

Title: From Scale up to Scale Out - Migrating our App from Big Iron to the Cloud
Abstract:
Performance in the cloud comes from the ability to scale out.  Unfortunately, your options to scale up instead of out in the cloud can often be limited and in some cases even the biggest cloud instance you can provision is far less powerful than the on premise server you are migrating from.  

This presentation will share techniques and lessons learned from real world experience when deploying large existing ASP.Net/SQL Server applications to Windows Azure.   While some abstract concepts will be discussed, the primary focus of this presentation will be to give attendees practical technical solutions that can be applied to dramatically improve performance in the cloud without major code/architecture changes and in many cases the techniques covered in this presentation are also highly effective in non-cloud environments.

Title: From Visual Studio to Android Studio
Abstract: This session provides an introduction to building native Android apps using Android Studio. Topics are covered from the perspective of someone with .NET experience but are appropriate for anyone looking to get into the mobile space. We will begin by learning what Android has to offer and then build our first small, but functional application.

Title: From Zero to Full Deployment Automation in 60 Minutes
Abstract:
Wouldn’t it be nice if the simple action of checking in your latest changes into source control triggered an official build? Wouldn’t it be even better if, upon a successful build, the latest executables were automatically deployed to your test bed without you lifting a finger? If you’re not lucky enough to be deploying to a cloud platform that provides such functionality out of the box, automating your process might seem daunting. In this session, Danielle will demonstrate how you can leverage tools such as TeamCity and Octopus Deploy to automate your builds and deployments. You’ll be introduced to a variety of options you can use to customize the process in order to meet your particular requirements. Along the way, you’ll learn about some neat productivity features you may wish to leverage as well as some pitfalls you would do well to avoid.

You’ll leave this session with the knowledge of how to automate your own builds and deployments and how to extend that automation chain so you can reach the next level.  Test automation, anyone?

Title: Front-End Style Guides from 0 to 60!
Abstract: Over the course of the workshop learn techniques related to building, maintaining, and scaling front-end style guides. Attendees will learn the history of style guides, see examples of great style guides done by small and large companies alike, and start building their own style guide.

Title: Galileo Magnifico! IoT with Windows on Devices
Abstract: We are in the era of the Maker. Never before has DIY-type hardware been so accessible and affordable. The plethora of devices and sensors at our fingertips is staggering, giving us the power to bring our ideas to fruition. Microsoft recently unveiled their Windows on Devices developer program that brings a small Windows OS to a small device, in this case the Intel Galileo. The first preview enables developers to use Visual Studio to program and execute Arduino sketches on the Galileo. This session will provide an overview of the developer program, how to get started with Windows on the Galileo as well as a demonstration of a couple of projects.

Title: Generating Circumstances
Abstract:
Most samples, fixtures, stubs tend to fall short of completing their intended storyline: representing the range of possible values that will interact with a single specification or a test on something more elaborate and integrated. Why not just set some constraints and/or bounds and generate a more exhaustive set of circumstances that your program or system is contracted and believed to satisfy?

In this talk, I'll cover using test.check to easily compose and apply generators and how we're generating a comprehensive set of values from Prismatic schemas, which we use as our integral validation layer. We apply these generations toward all kinds of problem spaces, including forming testable database environments, collection filtering, and our property-based tests for capturing what's true/valid and what better be false.

Title: Generics in .NET
Abstract: All .NET developers have used generics, but too few utilize their full power.  Most developers who use generics think of them only for collections, when they are valuable in any situation where code is the same except for type.  This session is a deep dive into generic classes, interfaces, methods, and delegates.  You will learn how to increase the power of generics by applying constraints, and will see examples drawn from real applications.  You will leave with ideas about how to apply generics in your development and understanding the .NET features necessary to realize those ideas.

Title: Get Shipping with Docker
Abstract:
Docker is a platform for building, shipping and running distributed applications. It solves the problem of managing an application's dependencies in a simple and automated way. Google, IBM, Red Hat, Amazon, and even Microsoft are all on board with it. This hands-on session will cover what Docker is, how to use it, and what it can do for you and your organization. 

You will:

* Understand the purpose of Docker and the concepts of images, containers and repositories

* Install Docker on your laptop and run standard Docker images 

* Learn strategies for building layered Docker images 

* Create, run and debug your own Docker image 

* Receive an overview of advanced Docker container concepts like volume mounting and IP port forwarding 

* Be introduced to Fig (fast, isolated development environments) to easily manage a cluster of Docker containers
  
So come and get shipping with Docker!

Title: Get the most out of your text-based data
Abstract: It's your information, why don't you use it? Too many times, businesses and developers collect different forms of text-based data that then go unused, collecting dust in some data warehouse. This session will introduce developers to several ways businesses are leveraging text analytics and natural language processing to improve business practices or inform decision-making processes. Types of data used in the examples may include company websites, invoices, record narratives and social media. The majority of examples and tools demonstrated will be python based. The means to extract usable, structured information from unstructured text and add it to your data arsenal is within your grasp!

Title: Get your game on with Unity and Oculus Rift!
Abstract: Coming Soon

Title: Getting Good at Gradle
Abstract: Now that you have made the choice to use gradle, what’s next? In this session, you will learn how turn the build from something everyone tries to avoid intro something you can actually love. Find out about strategies for making build scripts that are actually maintainable as well as some of the cooler advanced features you should be aware of and could be making use of starting today. What’s new in Gradle 2? What are some of the leaders in the industry doing with gradle? Finally learn how gradle fits nicely in your continuous delivery pipeline.

Title: Getting Sassy With CSS
Abstract:
I don’t know about you, but vanilla CSS always leaves me wanting more. It’s a fairly simple language, can do some pretty powerful things, but after a while... well, it can become rather tedious to work with. 

Enter Sass: Syntactically Awesome Stylesheets. Sass is a CSS meta-language and precompiler that makes the prettification of your website a breeze by adding invaluable features of more traditional programming languages. 

In this workshop, we’ll jump right in to the Sass workflow and cover all the key game changers - nesting, variables, mixins, inheritance, and directives. We’ll also cover some of the gotchyas, tools and extensions, and tips on organization and coding standards.

Title: Getting Sassy With CSS : Sass Shop
Abstract:
I don’t know about you, but vanilla CSS always leaves me wanting more. It’s a fairly simple language, can do some pretty powerful things, but after a while... well, it can become rather tedious to work with. 

Enter Sass: Syntactically Awesome Stylesheets. Sass is a CSS meta-language and precompiler that makes the prettification of your website a breeze by adding invaluable features of more traditional programming languages. 

In this workshop, we’ll jump right in to the Sass workflow and cover all the key game changers - nesting, variables, mixins, inheritance, and directives. We’ll also cover some of the gotchyas, tools and extensions, and tips on organization and coding standards.

Title: Getting Started with Chrome Extensions: Tips and Tricks
Abstract: You’ve seen Chrome extensions in the wild, maybe even installed a few into your browser — but what about writing your own? In this talk, you’ll learn the basics of Chrome extension development (from git init to publishing in the Web Store), how to avoid having your extension automatically disabled when performing upgrades, and some unexpected parts of Chrome you can hook into to take your extension to the next level.

Title: Getting Started with Machine Learning on Azure
Abstract: Machine Learning can often be a daunting subject to tackle much less utilize in a meaningful manner. In this session, attendees will learn how to take their existing data, shape it, and create models that automatically can make principled business decisions directly in their applications. The discussion will include explanations of the data acquisition and shaping process. Additionally, attendees will learn the basics of machine learning on the Azure platform- primarily the supervised learning problem.

Title: git gone wild: how to recover from common git mistakes.
Abstract:
"Oh no! I just typed something into git and now my work is gone! Ahh!"

Don't panic. Contrary to popular belief, git is one of the most non-destructive version control systems available. When used right, git
never loses any data, and even when misused, chances are very high you can still recover.

This talk will present turn-by-turn directions on how to recover from a wide array of common git mistakes, and also provide some workflows
to minimize them.

Title: Gitting More Out of Git
Abstract:
Having trouble groking git? Not sure what the difference between merging and rebasing is? Wondering what you would ever use a "cherry-pick" for? We'll cover these topics and more in this talk, helping you get past git novice and on your way to git master.

We'll do a short review of git, then dive deeper into: branches, commit amending, git logs, merging and rebasing,  cherry-picking, stashing, and more.

Okay, maybe you won't be a guru after one conference session, but you will have a better understanding of how to play nicely with others in the same git repository.

Title: Going Indie 101: Lessons Learned from a Over a Decade of Independence
Abstract:
Breaking free from the confines of the cubicle farm and going out on your own can be one of the most satisfying things you do for your career. It can also be one of the most terrifying. Being on your own can seem like it's nothing but ponies, unicorns and rainbows, but it's a lot of work, and success is not guaranteed.

 Mike, an independent developer since 2001, will discuss the lesson's he's learned over the years along with the ups and downs he's experienced. In this updated and expanded session, he will be joined by friend and attorney Jeffrey Strauss to help answer the most common questions he's been asked over the years. "How do I get started?", "Where do I find clients?", "How much do I charge?", "Do I need a contract?" and many others. Bring your questions and find out if the grass really is greener on the other side.

Title: Grails and AngularJS, bridging the gap
Abstract: This will be a presentation on my experience integrating existing  Grails services and Assets with AngularJS. Most Grails developers are very reliant on GSPs to display structured data. With the introduction of a more powerful and standardized mobile platform some of this can be offloaded to the browser. This class will explore issues such as Angular directives and services, Grails service calls, web sockets and more. We will ensure functionality and code quality throughout the stack using Jasmine, Spock and CucumberJs tests.  Finally, if there is still time we will look into using the Grails Bootstrap Plugin to allow for clean and easy theming. These are both very powerful technologies, and for those businesses not ready for NodeJS this is a great alternative.

Title: Growth: Moving Beyond “Independent Developer”
Abstract: You’ve made the decision to go out on your own. Do you want to stay an Army of One or do you strive for something more? Spend an hour discussing the obstacles you will encounter if you go it alone and the obstacles you will encounter if you don’t. Learn philosophies that will help you on your way to an Army of Two, from before, to during, and for after your transition to Employer. Move beyond Independent Developer, and switch from “Me” to “Us”.

Title: Hadoop and Beyond: Advances in Big Data Processing
Abstract:
As we deploy apps generating more data, at a faster pace, we need to bring a new set of tools to help us handle it.  In this pre-compiler, we'll look at 4 key big data workloads, Query at Scale, NoSQL, Streaming, and Machine Learning, and how to incorporate them into your applications.
